content.text: HSV keratitis is a common cause of infectious corneal blindness in the developed world. It is typically caused by HSV-1. After a primary infection (often asymptomatic), the virus establishes latency in the trigeminal ganglion. Reactivation can be triggered by factors like fever, stress, sunlight, or immunosuppression, leading to recurrent ocular disease.

This is the most common form, caused by active viral replication in the corneal epithelium. The classic sign is a dendritic ulcer, a linear branching lesion that stains with fluorescein. Patients often experience pain, photophobia, and blurred vision. Corneal sensation is typically reduced.

This is an immune-mediated response to viral antigens in the corneal stroma, not active viral replication. It can present as necrotizing stromal keratitis (with inflammation and tissue destruction) or non-necrotizing (interstitial) keratitis (with stromal haze and ghost vessels). It can lead to significant scarring.

This is an inflammatory reaction in the corneal endothelium. It presents as a disc-shaped area of corneal edema, often with keratic precipitates (inflammatory cells on the endothelium). It is an immunologic reaction, not an active infection.

appliesTo.description: Patients with active HSV epithelial disease

regimenData.notes: Topical antivirals are the mainstay. Oral acyclovir is equally effective and often better tolerated. Topical steroids are contraindicated.

This is treated with topical corticosteroids to control the inflammation, always under the cover of a prophylactic oral antiviral to prevent epithelial recurrence. This must be managed by an ophthalmologist.

appliesTo.description: Patients with a history of stromal keratitis or multiple recurrences

criteriaBasedDuration.description: Long-term, often for at least 1 year.

regimenData.notes: Long-term oral antiviral prophylaxis has been shown by the Herpetic Eye Disease Study (HEDS) to reduce the rate of recurrence of all forms of ocular HSV disease.

content.text: Also known as Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO), this occurs when VZV reactivates in the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. Hutchinson's sign (a rash on the tip of the nose) indicates a high likelihood of ocular involvement. Ocular manifestations are similar to HSV, including conjunctivitis, keratitis (pseudodendrites), stromal keratitis, and uveitis.

regimenData.notes: High-dose oral antivirals should be started within 72 hours of rash onset to reduce the severity and duration of the rash and to decrease the risk and severity of ocular complications and postherpetic neuralgia.
